alert.note: Alert for Carver; Dakota; Hennepin; Scott (Minnesota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 22 at 10:01AM CDT until May 28 at 7:00AM CDT by NWS Minneapolis
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Minnesota... Minnesota River near Jordan affecting Carver, Scott and Sibley Counties. Minnesota River at Savage affecting Dakota, Carver, Scott and Hennepin Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Minnesota... Minnesota River At New Ulm affecting Brown, Blue Earth and Nicollet Counties. Sauk River at St. Cloud affecting Stearns County. Minnesota River At Morton affecting Redwood and Renville Counties. Minnesota River at Montevideo affecting Lac qui Parle, Chippewa and Yellow Medicine Counties. .Forecast points continue falling with the exception of the Minnesota River at Jordan and Savage as the final flood wave moves downstream. This is also why the Mississippi at Saint Paul is having a extended crest as it is just downstream of the confluence of the two rivers. With no significant precipitation forecast for the next few days current trends are expected to continue. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL SATURDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Minnesota River at Savage. * WHEN...Until Saturday morning. * IMPACTS...At 702.0 feet, Barge loading stops at Port Cargill, and other flood prevention measures are begun. Water begins to impact Black Dog Road in Burnsville. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 900 AM CDT Sunday, the stage was 702.9 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 900 AM CDT Sunday was 702.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 703.2 feet early tomorrow afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage early Friday afternoon. - Flood stage is 702.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 703.4 feet on 06/29/2011. &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
